pages.text: Your forge is limited to burning Coal-based fuels. This usually means $(thing)Charcoal$(), but also dug up coals like $(thing)Bituminous Coal$() or $(thing)Lignite$(). In this chapter, we will see processed versions of these fuels.

pages.title: Coal Pellets
pages.text: Just like lumber, $(thing)Charcoal$() can be ground up into a powder. That powder can be compressed again, to make $(thing)Charcoal Pellets$(). These burn for slightly longer than regular coal, at the expense of quern durability.

pages.title: Grinding Coals
pages.text: In order to make coal pellets, you need to ground up $(thing)Charcoal$(), $(thing)Bituminous Coal$() or $(thing)Lignite$() in a $(thing)Quern$() . Bituminous coal has bigger yield (6 dust) compared to Lignite.

pages.title: Coke
pages.text: Coke is a form of proceesed coal where the coal is burned in similar conditions to charcoal(airless environment) in order to purify it, producing greater temperatures.
$(thing)Coal Dust$() can be heated up at any place to burn out and become $(thing)Coke Dust$(). There is a 20% chance that the Coal Dust will burn to nothing, otherwise, it will turn into coke.

$(thing)Coke Powder$() needs to be compressed into $(thing)Coke Pellets$() in order to be burnable. Same with $(thing)Coal Powder$() for $(thing)Coal Pellets$(). You can also compress $(thing)Graphite Pellets$(), but those cannot burn by themselves.

pages.title: Briquettes
pages.text: Compressing those pellets further using some glue will give you $(thing)Briquettes$(). They burn for 5 times as long as the pellets they are made of, and can be stored in log piles!

pages.title: Special Briquettes
pages.text: Some Briquettes can be a mix of two or more types of Pellets. These mixes will be detailed here.

pages.title: Coke-Charcoal Briquette
pages.text: Using half Charcoal, Half Coke, you can produce a briquette that burns higher than charcoal for a longer duration.

pages.title: Diluted Charcoal Briquette
pages.text: Using half Charcoal, Half Wood, you can produce a briquette that burns at a lower temperature than charcoal for a longer duration. It burns below the melting point of bronze

pages.title: Low Temperature Charcoal Briquette
pages.text: Using 1/4 Charcoal, 3/4 Wood, you can produce a briquette that burns at a even lower temperature than charcoal for an even longer duration! It burns at a slightly higher temperature than $(thing)Bamboo Firelogs$(), and can also be used in the Firepit.

pages.title: High-Intensity Charcoal Briquette
pages.text: Using 6 Charcoal, for a Graphite and a Coke, you can produce a briquette that burns at a impossibly high temperature for a shorter duration.
